txt: How can the current system be appealed or questioned?
Soils can be manipulated. Why regulate uses based on soils?
LSB is out of date because irrigation infrastructure has changed
We regularly consult LSB ratings when assessing agricultural potential for land. It provides a useful baseline..
We should be cautious about major changes to systems that still work reasonably well..
A major limitation of current systems is the lack of regular updates to reflect changing conditions..
The LSB system undervalues land quality in some regions..
Digital soil maps like SSURGO offer more detailed insights, but can be difficult to interpret without adequate training..
Periodic re-evaluation and stakeholder input would help keep existing systems relevant..
It's challenging to reconcile differences between multiple classification systems on the same land..
Protecting prime productive lands should remain a priority in agricultural land regulation..
Existing classifications overly focus on productivity, which shouldn't be the only consideration..
Existing systems don't account for climate change or traditional Hawaiian land management..
Special Use Permit process focuses on LSB, but others are considered as well.
Need for a robust modern system that supports agricultural productivity and regulation (via protection).
Systems were designed to protect sugar and pine do not reflect current use, diversified use, agriculture on marginal lands or taro farming
Updating soil systems could assist LUC to create new SLUD category to allow for other (non urban/non ag) uses
Consideration of economic value of agricultural output, beyond just soil quality, could improve classification
Enclosed agriculture (vertical, shade, green houses etc) needs to be considered in any system update
SWCD planners need to consider soil qualities (ie erosion) in their conservation planning
Productivity is part of the issue, need to consider previous and potential uses (hydroponics, etc)
Distance to services and history of use are important considerations
IAL is based on ag productivity and protecting those lands
Soil classifications should take into account ahupuaa and indigenous perspectives, justice, land access, and water access.
Rural classification was created to be a buffer between ag and urban use
Need to look at how soil and labor will shape the future of ag
Soil types are important to identify traditional/cultural resources and vegetation.
Water infrastructure is needed to ensure IAL and similar lands are able to be utilized
Water availability should be considered. Even if there are great soils, if waster is not available, extensive ag may not be possible.
Soil systems should be easy to use and understand
Having a soil classification system is helpful for providing a policy framework
Need for a robust modern system that supports agricultural PRODUCTIVITY
The LSB soil classification system feels outdated
Data should be updated to reflect how lands are currently being used
The current land classification system is embedded in the racist dispossession of kanaka maoli
Education about soil classifications is important to inform project design.
New criteria should be included in agricultural land regulation
Vertical farming should not be used as a diversion to authorize development of Agricultural lands.
Soil remediation is not considered in the current assessment of soil quality.
Permaculture is a popular system in Hawaii County.  It does not need flat lands, but it can still be productive.
Protecting prime productive lands should remain a FACTOR in agricultural land regulation..
Different classification system each for crops, grazing/livestock, vertical farming, ornamentals, hydroponics.
Be clearer about what soil classification is classifying. If it is more than soil quality, be clearer about all factors in the index.
Any system incorporating soils for land use decisions should be updatable, dynamic, and easily incorporated into land use decisions
Vertical Farming is the future, like EVs.  Cannot disregard it.
Only LSB contains crop/animal yield estimates that are useful to farmers
The State should hold managers and owners accountable for fallow ag lands or crops that have little use in our lives (i.e., pineapple).
We need to release ag land for energy use.
A modern classification system should prioritize land for local consumption, not pure productivity
Systems like SSURGO should release original data to allow users to do their own interpolation
As technologies develop there may be land available that just needs water once or occasionally.  Agua culture!  What else is developing??
Soil carbon data is highly spatially interpolated and can be unreliable
submtting separately
This statement is 2 issues.  As for climate change there are many adaptable crops.
SSURGO is useful for identify inputs to see if lands are economically feasible.
Utilizing hydroponic or aquaponic farming renders preservation of agricultural lands solely based on soil classification obsolete
Outdated data underlying the SSURGO soil classifications limits usefulness in climate mitigation and adaptation forecasting
Soil class systems don't consider the remediation many soils now require before anything can be grown safely (must be bioremediation).
Classification maps and indexes must be modernized to optimize for those factors of value in Hawaii today, i.e., not just productivity
Collective indices of "resilience" should be developed as a system to underlie a new classification system
utilizing land for more than one state priority should be considered since some land has multiple potential priorities
Indigenous values and water rights should be centered in the development of a classification system that may be used for land use regulation
Land and soil classifications must base their designations on a systems-based understanding of land use
There are too many systems. They need to be congruent.
Dynamic soil properties, like soil health, should be part of a new classification system
Resilience should be a factor: water availability, natural and cultural resources, future climate, crop suitability, regenerative capacity.
SSURGO needs to be updated to include relevant, local data and methodologies for collecting data about Hawaii's soils
SSURGO is useful for waterflow and erosion analysis for housing developments
A statewide update to SSURGO would be useful
OPSD uses OSPD and ALISH when reviewing land use district boundary amendments that go before the LUC
Soils could be classified based on potential for improvement in soil quality and health or as a factors in climate mitigation
Soil classifications are one tool in the toolbox, but may not be the best way to determine land use priorities
Underlying geology and land use and land position (mauka/makai)
Systems need updating, but we need to have a system that isn’t constantly being updated too
LSB’s soil productivity approach should be foundation for any update, additional considerations and uses could be add-ons but not the focus.
Pastureland should be separated from agricultural lands. Not less important, just separate, based on the quantity of food produced alone.
Underlying geology and land use and land position (mauka/makai) should be considered
Any new system should not be so oversimplified that bad actors manipulate/take advantage of it
The State should come up with a cohesive classification of what use proper use of prime lands and isn't.
Important to ID how differences in historical vs. current use will be incorporated (ex. loi ~100 yrs ago, now developed or filled, etc.)
LSB classes C and lowers are used to discount land quality and upzone, despite agricultural potential
A land's potential for soil carbon sequestration should be considered in any new integrated framework
xxx
Uncertainty should be explicitly stated and included, even if large
Soils that have high potential for carbon sequestration management
Soils with high potential for sustained food production with minimal nutrient export (for ecosystem health)
Soils that have undergone or continue to be at high risk of massive erosion.
Agrivoltaics can help stimulate agriculture in areas that have not recently been used for agriculture.
Class A land should also be allowed for renewable energy use if there is an appropriate and approved agriculture plan for the land.
climate change effects on endangered species movement needs to be also addressed
identify AG lands that could be rehabilitated and not just classified as A and B classifications
how will the data be updated - per legislative session, etc?
Some of the comments are more technical than I am familiar with, but I do understand the need for a new large update andconsistent updates.
LSB soil classifications appear to be arbitrary compared to current use of parcels
The classification system needs to recognize that there is a need for both agricultural productivity as well as energy production
Site specific soil studies determine that the existing classifications are inaccurate
LSB is the primary system used in solar scoping due to use in land regulation
Outdated LSB layers don’t reflect possible use
Food sustainability is more important than energy production.
The system should consider a classification for land that can be used for dual purposes like agrivoltaics (plants/crops or animals)
The priority of any classification should be identifying the ground truth rather than agreeing with current classifications
Energy versus food production is a false dichotomy.
Soils that are being used for food security should receive a higher soil classification rating
The LSB system is fine because soils don't change over time.
The soil classification system needs an appeal process
An updated soils survey should be completed since soils have eroded and composition has changed due to topsoil loss
The opportunity to analyze soil classification should focus on protecting ag lands and not an opportunity to lose more land to non-ag uses
In Hawaii, there is a need for soil monitoring with changes in land management and ongoing erosion
Regulation based on agricultural land classification system - land for variety of crops/uses, existing specialty crops, and Hawaiian crops.
Soil type/classification needs to inform the design of individual wastewater systems, especially in proximity to the coast/water.
“Highest and best” land use is to increase our collective resilience. Soil classification is one factor in determining potential.
Land , and vegetative condition could be a fact of use for land conversion
Regarding food sustainability and energy production these issues should be approached simultaneously if possible
What capacity are we considering for renewable energy development? Power the specific plot of land for ag prodution?
There are extensive data sets compiled from modern geotechnical literature that should be used in developing the current study
There should be a clear distinction between technical land classification schema and land use policy/designation schema
Modern Geotech datasets should be integrated into current soil classifications
Input layers should be provided along with any final classifications
Complex boundary lines that incorporate multiple layers aren’t well tailored for regulatory functions
It is challenging to hold landowners accountable for land conditions when market determines use
Soil sampling should occur regularly in order to know what the composition is and the determines the success of the crop.
Soil classifications should consider highly erodible land during updates
Soil class. should consider comprehensive economic considerations. For ex, is it ag vs energy, ag + energy, food vs fiber, or food + fiber?
Regulation incorporating soil classifications would happen more quickly at the county level vs the legislature
Consider the old wth the new.
It would be good if conservation plans coming through the soil and water districts included reference to local soil classification systems.
How might a classification system help incentivize soil remediation and GHG sequestration on working lands?
Existing systems don't account for climate change or traditional Hawaiian land management.  Separate into two questions.
Does crosscutting issues, like agrivoltaics, demonstrate some limitations to thinking behind more static classification systems?
Hard to strike the balance between long-term preservation of ag land and updates to that system that reflect changing land use dynamics
A project at UH to consider is the Benchmark Soils Project, which proved that ag technologies can be transferred based on Soil Series.
Agroforestry was a widespread traditional practice and important today. Traditional agroforestry areas are usually classified as marginal
the system should consider forestry potential when classifying soil. Sustainable native timber forestry is an emerging industry in Hawaii
what "productive" ag lands means is different to a soil scientist, a farmer, a land owner, an investor...
remote sensing technologies can be used to regularly inform us on soil conditions and changes
Agree that crop land should be distinct from pasture land but not based, but disagree that food quantity should be a consideration.
Options for solar production within urban areas should be exhausted before use of prime agricultural lands for photovoltaics.
The State and County should agree on one type of soil classification.
It isn’t a loss for agriculture to have photovoltaic if it’s agrivoltaic.  It’s been seen to be a benefit in some cases.
Systems should consider land cover change as a result of sea level rise.
Intensity of water use by the land user should be a factor in a rating.
Systems should consider the impact of invasive species (eg weeds, deer), on land degradation and its subsequent suitability for agriculture
Minimize administrative costs for managing soil classifications by streamlining processes with digital systems.
Pasturelands should be a distinct category within the classification system
In order to provide a systematic approach to soils, wetlands/hydric soils should be added to the soil classification systems.
Loopholes that allow for Gentlemen Estates must be addressed to ensure proper use of agricultural lands.
There should be a mandatory quota for production on agricultrual lands to ensure agricultural lands remain productive.
Agricultural activities that benefit the surrounding ecology and improve ecosystem services need to be prioritized and incentivized.
Mahalo
This process should focus on soil classification, what is the soil composition, porosity, etc at a specific point of time.
Soil classification should be just one factor in many to determine the best use of land, and "best  use" should not be limited to economics
To protect important ag lands need good soil types, relatively flat, have gravity-flow non-potable water. Stop interbasin transfer of water.
The LSB soil classifications should not be used as a system of regulatory land-use zoning.
Combining renewable energy with agriculture on Class-A land could make farming and ranching more successful.
Thanks
Land classification should include fuel load growth potential, fire susceptibility of lands and fire management options.
Important ag lands need good soil types, relatively flat, have gravity-flow non-potable water.
Soil classification should be just one factor in many to determine the best use of land
"best use" should not be limited to economics
The statements only referred to LSB. Why aren't ALISH and LESA systems being discussed?
Statements only refer to LSB. The ALISH and LESA systems have qualities that should be included in any agriculture and soil discussion.
Should ALISH and LESA systems be considered in land use, agriculture and soil discussions?
ALISH and LESA systems should be used when considering land use, agriculture and soil qualities.
ALISH and LESA systems should be considered when discussing land use, agriculture and soil qualities.
Real-time updated systems are very costly and may not be a reasonable use for policymaking.
That would depend by on users financial abilities
County of Hawaii has determined Ag Tax exemptions based on soil rating and not on how the land is used. This is a problem for ranchers.
Classifications and updates should be based on new scientific learning about soil, not just creating a new numbering system.
Thanks for the follow-up survey
I am concerned about how the superficial nature of this input consolidation system will affect the outcome of this important project.
Technology and public input could enable more precise, frequently-updated models..
